title: Anesthesia - what to ask your doctor - child: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Anesthesia - What to Ask Your Doctor - Child**

Your child is scheduled to have a surgery or procedure. You will need to talk with your child's surgeon about the type of anesthesia that will be best for your child.

**Questions Before Anesthesia**

* Which type of anesthesia is best for my child and the procedure that my child is having?
	+ General anesthesia
	+ Spinal or epidural anesthesia
	+ Conscious sedation
* When does my child need to stop eating or drinking before the anesthesia? What if my child is breastfeeding?
* When do my child and I need to get to the hospital on the day of the surgery? Is the rest of our family allowed to be there too?
* If my child is taking the following medicines, what should I do?
	+ Aspirin, ibuprofen (Motrin, Advil), naproxen (Aleve), arthritis medicines, vitamin E, warfarin (Coumadin), or any other medicines that make it hard for the child's blood to clot
	+ Vitamins, minerals, herbs, or other supplements
	+ Medicines for heart problems, lung problems, diabetes, allergies, or seizures
	+ Other medicines the child is supposed to take everyday
* If my child has asthma, diabetes, seizures, heart disease, or any other medical problems, do I need to do anything special before my child has anesthesia?
* Can my child take a tour of the surgery and recovery areas of the hospital before the surgery?

**Questions During Anesthesia**

* Will my child be awake or aware of what is happening?
* Will my child feel any pain?
* Will someone be watching to make sure my child is OK?
* How long may I stay with my child?

**Questions After Anesthesia**

* How soon will my child wake up?
* When can I see my child?
* How soon before my child can get up and move around?
* How long will my child need to stay?
* Will my child have any pain?
* Will my child have an upset stomach?
* If my child had spinal or epidural anesthesia, will my child have a headache afterwards?
* What if I have more questions after the surgery? Who can I contact?

---

**What to Ask Your Doctor About Anesthesia - Child**

Are you a parent wondering what questions to ask your doctor about anesthesia for your child? Look no further! This article will guide you through the process of preparing your child for surgery and understanding the different types of anesthesia.

**Before Anesthesia**

*   Which type of anesthesia is best for my child and the procedure that my child is having?
    *   General anesthesia
    *   Spinal or epidural anesthesia
    *   Conscious sedation
*   When does my child need to stop eating or drinking before the anesthesia? What if my child is breastfeeding?
*   When do my child and I need to get to the hospital on the day of the surgery? Is the rest of our family allowed to be there too?
*   If my child is taking the following medicines, what should I do?
    *   Aspirin, ibuprofen (Motrin, Advil), naproxen (Aleve), arthritis medicines, vitamin E, warfarin (Coumadin), or any other medicines that make it hard for the child's blood to clot
    *   Vitamins, minerals, herbs, or other supplements
    *   Medicines for heart problems, lung problems, diabetes, allergies, or seizures
*   If my child has asthma, diabetes, seizures, heart disease, or any other medical problems, do I need to do anything special before my child has anesthesia?
*   Can my child take a tour of the surgery and recovery areas of the hospital before the surgery?

**During Anesthesia**

*   Will my child be awake or aware of what is happening?
*   Will my child feel any pain?
*   Will someone be watching to make sure my child is OK?
*   How long may I stay with my child?

**After Anesthesia**

*   How soon will my child wake up?
*   When can I see my child?
*   How soon before my child can get up and move around?
*   How long will my child need to stay?
*   Will my child have any pain?
*   Will my child have an upset stomach?
*   If my child had spinal or epidural anesthesia, will my child have a headache afterwards?
*   What if I have more questions after the surgery? Who can I contact?

**Additional Tips**

*   Make sure to ask your doctor about any specific instructions or precautions you need to take before and after the surgery.
*   Consider taking notes during your conversation with your doctor to refer back to later.
*   Don't hesitate to ask follow-up questions if you're unsure about anything.

By asking the right questions, you can ensure that your child receives the best possible care during their surgical procedure.

title: Anesthesia: MedlinePlus
content:
**Anesthesia**

**What is Anesthesia?**

Anesthesia is the use of medicines to prevent pain during surgery and other procedures. These medicines are called anesthetics. They may be given by injection, inhalation, topical lotion, spray, eye drops, or skin patch. They cause you to have a loss of feeling or awareness.

**What is Anesthesia Used For?**

Anesthesia may be used in minor procedures, such as filling a tooth. It could be used during childbirth or procedures such as colonoscopies. And it is used during minor and major surgeries.

In some cases, a dentist, nurse, or doctor may give you an anesthetic. In other cases, you may need an anesthesiologist. This is a doctor who specializes in giving anesthesia.

**Types of Anesthesia**

There are several different types of anesthesia:

* **Local Anesthesia**: numbs a small part of the body. It might be used on a tooth that needs to be pulled or on a small area around a wound that needs stitches. You are awake and alert during local anesthesia.
* **Regional Anesthesia**: is used for larger areas of the body such as an arm, a leg, or everything below the waist. You may be awake during the procedure, or you may be given sedation. Regional anesthesia may be used during childbirth, a Cesarean delivery (C-section), or minor surgeries.
* **General Anesthesia**: affects the whole body. It makes you unconscious and unable to move. It is used during major surgeries, such as heart surgery, brain surgery, back surgery, and organ transplants.

**Risks of Anesthesia**

Anesthesia is generally safe. But there can be risks, especially with general anesthesia, including:

* Heart rhythm or breathing problems
* Allergic reaction to the anesthesia
* Delirium after general anesthesia. Delirium makes people confused. They may be unclear about what is happening to them.
* Awareness when someone is under general anesthesia. This usually means that the person hears sounds. But sometimes they can feel pain.

**Start Here**

If you are considering anesthesia for a procedure, it's essential to understand the different types of anesthesia and their risks. Anesthesiologists are specialized doctors who administer anesthesia. They will help you determine the best course of action for your specific needs.

**Treatments and Therapies**

Herbal and Dietary Supplements and Anesthesia (American Society of Anesthesiologists) - PDF
Anesthesia Awareness (Waking Up) During Surgery (American Society of Anesthesiologists)
Anesthesia Recovery (American Society of Anesthesiologists)
Effects of Anesthesia (American Society of Anesthesiologists)
Preparing for Surgery: Checklist (American Society of Anesthesiologists)
Role of the Anesthesiologist (American Society of Anesthesiologists)

**Related Issues**

Spinal Headaches (Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research)
Epidural Injections (American College of Radiology; Radiological Society of North America)
Obesity (American Society of Anesthesiologists)
Outpatient Surgery (American Society of Anesthesiologists)
Speak Up: Anesthesia and Sedation  (Joint Commission) - PDF

**Specifics**

Epidural Injections (American College of Radiology; Radiological Society of North America)
Obesity (American Society of Anesthesiologists)
Outpatient Surgery (American Society of Anesthesiologists)

**See, Play and Learn**

**Anesthesia**

Anesthesia is the use of medicines to prevent pain during surgery and other procedures. These medicines are called anesthetics, and they may be given by injection, inhalation, topical lotion, spray, eye drops, or skin patch.

**Types of Anesthesia**

There are several different types of anesthesia:

*   **Local Anesthesia**: numbs a small area of the body
*   **Regional Anesthesia**: numbs a larger area of the body, such as an arm or leg
*   **General Anesthesia**: puts the patient to sleep

**Risks of Anesthesia**

Anesthesia is generally safe. But there can be risks, especially with general anesthesia, including:

*   Heart rhythm or breathing problems
*   Allergic reaction to the anesthesia
*   Delirium after general anesthesia
*   Awareness when someone is under general anesthesia

**Who Gives Anesthesia?**

In some cases, a dentist, nurse, or doctor may give you an anesthetic. In other cases, you may need an anesthesiologist. This is a doctor who specializes in giving anesthesia.

**What to Expect During Surgery**

Before surgery, your doctor will explain the type of anesthesia you will receive and what to expect during the procedure. You may be given instructions on how to prepare for surgery and what to do after the procedure.

**Related Health Topics**

*   Pain
*   Surgery

---

**Anesthesia**

\n\n

**What is Anesthesia?**

Anesthesia is a medical term that refers to the use of medications or other methods to block pain during surgical procedures. There are several types of anesthesia, including general anesthesia, spinal and epidural anesthesia, conscious sedation for surgical procedures, and more.

\n\n

**Types of Anesthesia**

*   **General Anesthesia**: A type of anesthesia that puts a patient in a deep sleep, making them unconscious.
*   **Spinal and Epidural Anesthesia**: A type of anesthesia that numbs the lower part of the body, often used for childbirth or surgeries on the legs.
*   **Conscious Sedation for Surgical Procedures**: A type of anesthesia that helps patients relax during surgery while still being able to respond to questions.

\n\n

**Related Health Topics**

*   **Pain**: Anesthesia is often used to manage pain during surgical procedures.
*   **Surgery**: Anesthesia is a crucial part of many surgical procedures.

\n\n

title: Aneurysm in the brain: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Aneurysm in the Brain**

An aneurysm is a weak area in the wall of a blood vessel that causes the blood vessel to bulge or balloon out. When an aneurysm occurs in a blood vessel of the brain, it is called an intracranial aneurysm. These usually occur around or under the part of the brain called the cerebrum and, when this is true, are called a cerebral aneurysm.

**Causes**

Aneurysms around the brain occur when there is a weakened area in the wall of a blood vessel. An aneurysm may be present from birth (congenital). Or, it may develop later in life.

There are many types of brain aneurysms. The most common type is called a berry aneurysm. This type can vary in size from a few millimeters (mm) to over a centimeter (cm). Giant berry aneurysms can be bigger than 2.5 cm or 1 inch (in). These are more common in adults. Berry aneurysms, especially when there is more than one, are sometimes passed down through families.

**Risk Factors**

* Family history of cerebral aneurysms
* Medical problems such as polycystic kidney disease, coarctation of the aorta, and endocarditis
* High blood pressure, smoking, alcohol, and cocaine, methamphetamine, or amphetamine drug use

**Symptoms**

A person may have an aneurysm without having any symptoms. This kind of aneurysm may be found when an MRI or CT scan of the brain is done for another reason.

A brain aneurysm may begin to leak a small amount of blood. This may cause a severe headache that a person may describe as "the worst headache of my life." It may be called a thunderclap or sentinel headache. This means the headache could be a warning sign of a future rupture that may occur days to weeks after the headache first started.

Symptoms may also occur if the aneurysm pushes on nearby structures in the brain or breaks open (ruptures) and causes bleeding into the brain.

**Exams and Tests**

An eye exam may show signs of increased pressure in the brain, including swelling of the optic nerve or bleeding into the retina of the eye. A clinical exam may show abnormal eye movement, speech, strength, or sensation.

The following tests may be used to diagnose an intracranial or cerebral aneurysm and determine the cause of bleeding in the brain:

* Cerebral angiography or spiral CT angiogram (CTA) of the head to show the location and size of the aneurysm
* Spinal tap
* CT scan of the head
* Electrocardiogram (ECG)
* MRI of the head or MRI angiogram (MRA)

**Treatment**

Two common methods are used to repair a brain aneurysm.

Clipping is done during open brain surgery (craniotomy).
Endovascular repair is most often done. It usually involves placing a very small coil and possibly a stent (called coiling and stenting) into or around the aneurysm. This is a less invasive and most common way to treat aneurysms.

Not all aneurysms need to be treated right away. Those that are very small (less than 3 mm or 0.12 in) are less likely to break open.

Your health care provider will help you decide whether or not it is safer to have surgery to block off the aneurysm before it can break open. Sometimes people are too ill to have surgery, or it may be too dangerous to treat the aneurysm because of its location.

A ruptured aneurysm is an emergency that needs to be treated right away. Treatment may involve:

* Being admitted to a hospital's intensive care unit (ICU)
* Complete bed rest and activity restrictions
* Drainage of blood from the brain area (cerebral ventricular drainage)
* Medicines to prevent seizures
* Medicines to control headaches and blood pressure
* Medicines to prevent vasospasm, which is a constriction of the arteries of your brain, leading to decreased blood flow

Once the aneurysm is repaired, treatment may be needed to prevent a stroke from a blood vessel spasm.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

How well you do depends on many things. People who are in a deep coma after an aneurysm rupture do not do as well as those with less severe symptoms.

Ruptured cerebral aneurysms are often deadly. Of those who survive, some have no permanent disability. Others have moderate to severe disability.

**Possible Complications**

Complications of aneurysm in the brain may include:

* Increased pressure inside the skull
* Hydrocephalus, which is caused by an accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the ventricles of the brain
* Loss of movement in one or more parts of the body
* Loss of sensation of any part of the face or body
* Seizures
* Stroke
* Subarachnoid hemorrhage (bleeding around the brain)
* Intracerebral hemorrhage (bleeding in the brain)

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Go to the emergency room or call 911 or the local emergency number if you have a sudden or severe headache, especially if you also have nausea, vomiting, seizures, or any other nervous system symptom.

Also call if you have a headache that is unusual for you, especially if it is severe or your worst headache ever.

**Aneurysm in the Brain**

An aneurysm is a weak area in the wall of a blood vessel that causes the blood vessel to bulge or balloon out. When an aneurysm occurs in a blood vessel of the brain, it is called an intracranial aneurysm. These usually occur around or under the part of the brain called the cerebrum and, when this is true, are called a cerebral aneurysm.

**Causes**

Aneurysms around the brain occur when there is a weakened area in the wall of a blood vessel. An aneurysm may be present from birth (congenital). Or, it may develop later in life.

Giant berry aneurysms can be bigger than 2.5 cm or 1 inch (in). These are more common in adults. Berry aneurysms, especially when there is more than one, are sometimes passed down through families.

Watch this video about: Cerebral Aneurysm

Other types of cerebral aneurysms involve widening of an entire blood vessel (fusiform aneurysms). Aneurysms can occur in any blood vessel that supplies the brain. Hardening of arteries (atherosclerosis), trauma, and infection can all injure the blood vessel wall and cause cerebral aneurysms.

Brain aneurysms are relatively common. One in 50 people has a brain aneurysm, but only a small number of these aneurysms cause symptoms or rupture.

Risk factors include:

* Family history of cerebral aneurysms
* Medical problems such as polycystic kidney disease, coarctation of the aorta, and endocarditis
* High blood pressure, smoking, alcohol, and cocaine, methamphetamine, or amphetamine drug use

**Symptoms**

A person may have an aneurysm without having any symptoms. This kind of aneurysm may be found when an MRI or CT scan of the brain is done for another reason.

A brain aneurysm may begin to leak a small amount of blood. This may cause a severe headache that a person may describe as "the worst headache of my life." It may be called a thunderclap or sentinel headache. This means the headache could be a warning sign of a future rupture that may occur days to weeks after the headache first started.

Symptoms may also occur if the aneurysm pushes on nearby structures in the brain or breaks open (ruptures) and causes bleeding into the brain.

Symptoms depend on the location of the aneurysm, whether it breaks open, and what part of the brain it is pushing on. Symptoms may include:

* Double vision
* Loss of vision
* Headaches
* Eye pain
* Neck pain
* Stiff neck
* Ringing in the ears

A sudden, severe headache is one symptom of an aneurysm that has ruptured. Other symptoms of an aneurysm rupture may include:

* Confusion, no energy, sleepiness, or stupor
* Eyelid drooping
* Headaches with nausea or vomiting
* Muscle weakness or difficulty moving any part of the body
* Numbness or decreased sensation in any part of the body
* Problems speaking
* Seizures
* Stiff neck (occasionally)
* Vision changes (double vision, loss of vision)
* Loss of consciousness (coma)

NOTE: A ruptured aneurysm is a medical emergency. Call 911 or the local emergency number.

*   Double vision
*   Loss of vision
*   Headaches
*   Eye pain
*   Neck pain
*   Stiff neck
*   Ringing in the ears

    A sudden, severe headache is one symptom of an aneurysm that has ruptured. Other symptoms of an aneurysm rupture may include:

    *   Confusion, no energy, sleepiness, or stupor
    *   Eyelid drooping
    *   Headaches with nausea or vomiting
    *   Muscle weakness or difficulty moving any part of the body
    *   Numbness or decreased sensation in any part of the body
    *   Problems speaking
    *   Seizures
    *   Stiff neck (occasionally)
    *   Vision changes (double vision, loss of vision)
    *   Loss of consciousness (coma)

**Exams and Tests**

*   An eye exam may show signs of increased pressure in the brain, including swelling of the optic nerve or bleeding into the retina of the eye. A clinical exam may show abnormal eye movement, speech, strength, or sensation.
*   The following tests may be used to diagnose an intracranial or cerebral aneurysm and determine the cause of bleeding in the brain:
    *   Cerebral angiography or spiral CT angiogram (CTA) of the head to show the location and size of the aneurysm
    *   Spinal tap
    *   CT scan of the head
    *   Electrocardiogram (ECG)
    *   MRI of the head or MRI angiogram (MRA)

**Treatment**

*   Two common methods are used to repair a brain aneurysm.
    *   Clipping is done during open brain surgery (craniotomy).
    *   Endovascular repair is most often done. It usually involves placing a very small coil and possibly a stent (called coiling and stenting) into or around the aneurysm. This is a less invasive and most common way to treat aneurysms.
*   Not all aneurysms need to be treated right away. Those that are very small (less than 3 mm or 0.12 in) are less likely to break open.
*   Your health care provider will help you decide whether or not it is safer to have surgery to block off the aneurysm before it can break open. Sometimes people are too ill to have surgery, or it may be too dangerous to treat the aneurysm because of its location.
*   A ruptured aneurysm is an emergency that needs to be treated right away. Treatment may involve:
    *   Being admitted to a hospital's intensive care unit (ICU)
    *   Complete bed rest and activity restrictions
    *   Drainage of blood from the brain area (cerebral ventricular drainage)
    *   Medicines to prevent seizures
    *   Medicines to control headaches and blood pressure
    *   Medicines to prevent vasospasm, which is a constriction of the arteries of your brain, leading to decreased blood flow

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

*   How well you do depends on many things. People who are in a deep coma after an aneurysm rupture do not do as well as those with less severe symptoms.
*   Ruptured cerebral aneurysms are often deadly. Of those who survive, some have no permanent disability. Others have moderate to severe disability.

**Possible Complications**

*   Possible complications of an aneurysm in the brain may include:
    *   Seizures
    *   Stroke
    *   Coma
    *   Death

---

**Aneurysm in the Brain**

**Possible Complications**

*   Increased pressure inside the skull
*   Hydrocephalus, which is caused by an accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the ventricles of the brain
*   Loss of movement in one or more parts of the body
*   Loss of sensation of any part of the face or body
*   Seizures
*   Stroke
*   Subarachnoid hemorrhage (bleeding around the brain)
*   Intracerebral hemorrhage (bleeding in the brain)

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

If you have a sudden or severe headache, especially if you also have nausea, vomiting, seizures, or any other nervous system symptom. Also call if you have a headache that is unusual for you, especially if it is severe or your worst headache ever.

**Prevention**

There is no known way to prevent a berry aneurysm from forming. Treating high blood pressure may reduce the chance that an existing aneurysm will rupture. Controlling risk factors for atherosclerosis may reduce the likelihood of some types of aneurysms.

People who are known to have an aneurysm may need regular visits with their provider to make sure the aneurysm is not changing size or shape. If unruptured aneurysms are discovered in time, they can be treated before causing problems or monitored with regular imaging (usually yearly). The decision to repair an unruptured cerebral aneurysm is based on the size and location of the aneurysm, and the person's age and general health.

**Alternative Names**

*   Aneurysm - cerebral
*   Cerebral aneurysm
*   Aneurysm - intracranial

---

**Aneurysm in the Brain**

\n\n

**What is a cerebral aneurysm?**

A cerebral aneurysm, also known as a brain aneurysm, is a bulge or ballooning in one of the arteries that supply blood to the brain. It can be thought of as a weak spot in the artery wall where the pressure inside the artery causes it to stretch and eventually balloon out.

\n\n

**Types of cerebral aneurysms**

There are several types of cerebral aneurysms, including:

*   **Saccular aneurysm**: This is the most common type of cerebral aneurysm. It is a small, rounded bulge in the artery wall.
*   **Fusiform aneurysm**: This type of aneurysm is a long, narrow bulge in the artery wall.
*   **Dissecting aneurysm**: This type of aneurysm occurs when there is a tear in the inner layer of the artery wall.

\n\n

**Causes and risk factors**

The exact cause of cerebral aneurysms is not fully understood, but several factors can increase the risk of developing one. These include:

*   **Family history**: Having a family history of cerebral aneurysms or other vascular problems may increase your risk.
*   **Age**: Cerebral aneurysms are more common in people over 40 years old.
*   **Hypertension**: High blood pressure can weaken the artery walls and increase the risk of a cerebral aneurysm.
*   **Head trauma**: A severe blow to the head may cause a cerebral aneurysm.

\n\n

**Symptoms**

Cerebral aneurysms are often asymptomatic until they rupture, causing a subarachnoid hemorrhage. However, some people may experience symptoms such as:

*   **Severe headache**: A sudden, severe headache that can be described as the worst headache of your life.
*   **Confusion and disorientation**: A person who has experienced a cerebral aneurysm rupture may become confused and disoriented.

\n\n

**Treatment**

The treatment for cerebral aneurysms depends on several factors, including the size and location of the aneurysm, as well as the individual's overall health. Treatment options include:

*   **Surgical clipping**: This involves placing a small clip across the neck of the aneurysm to prevent it from rupturing.
*   **Endovascular coiling**: This involves using a catheter to deliver coils into the aneurysm, where they become lodged and prevent further bleeding.
*   **Observation**: In some cases, cerebral aneurysms may be small enough that they do not require treatment. Instead, the individual's doctor will monitor the aneurysm closely for any changes.

\n\n

**Prevention**

While it is not possible to completely prevent cerebral aneurysms, there are several steps you can take to reduce your risk:

*   **Manage hypertension**: Keeping your blood pressure under control can help reduce your risk of developing a cerebral aneurysm.
*   **Avoid head trauma**: Taking steps to avoid head trauma, such as wearing a seatbelt or helmet when necessary, can help reduce your risk.

\n\n

**References**

title: Aneurysm | MedlinePlus
content:
**Aneurysms**

An aneurysm is a bulge or "ballooning" in the wall of an artery. Arteries are blood vessels that carry oxygen-rich blood from the heart to other parts of the body. If an aneurysm grows large, it can burst and cause dangerous bleeding or even death.

**Where Do Aneurysms Occur?**

Most aneurysms occur in the aorta, the main artery that runs from the heart through the chest and abdomen. Aneurysms also can happen in arteries in the brain, heart, and other parts of the body. If an aneurysm in the brain bursts, it causes a stroke.

**Symptoms and Detection**

Aneurysms can develop and become large before causing any symptoms. Often doctors can stop aneurysms from bursting if they find and treat them early. They use imaging tests to find aneurysms. Often aneurysms are found by chance during tests done for other reasons.

**Treatments**

Medicines and surgery are the two main treatments for aneurysms.

**Learn More**

title: Aneurysm: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Aneurysm**

An aneurysm is an abnormal widening or ballooning of a part of an artery due to weakness in the wall of the blood vessel.

**Causes**

It is often not clear exactly what causes aneurysms. Some aneurysms are present at birth (congenital). Defects in some parts of the artery wall may be a cause.

* Major artery from the heart such as the thoracic or abdominal aorta
* Brain (cerebral aneurysm)
* Behind the knee (popliteal artery aneurysm)
* Intestine (mesenteric artery aneurysm)
* Artery in the spleen (splenic artery aneurysm)

Certain factors or conditions may increase the risk for aneurysms including:

* High blood pressure (thoracic, abdominal and cerebral aneurysms)
* High cholesterol
* Cigarette smoking
* Illicit drug use (cocaine, amphetamines, methamphetamine)
* Pregnancy (often linked to splenic artery aneurysms)
* Family history (sibling, parent, or child)

Inherited disorders that may increase the risk include:

* Fibromuscular dysplasia (abnormal cell growth in artery walls)
* Marfan syndrome
* Polycystic kidney disease
* Coarctation of the aorta
* Cerebral arteriovenous malformation (AVM)

**Symptoms**

The symptoms depend on where the aneurysm is located. If the aneurysm occurs near the body's surface, pain and swelling with a throbbing lump is often seen.

Aneurysms in the body or brain often cause no symptoms. Aneurysms in the brain may expand without breaking open (rupturing). The expanded aneurysm may press on nerves and cause double vision, dizziness, or headaches. Some aneurysms may cause ringing in the ears.

If an aneurysm ruptures, pain, low blood pressure, a rapid heart rate, and lightheadedness may occur. When a brain aneurysm ruptures, there is a sudden severe headache that some people say is the "worst headache of my life." The risk of neurologic injury, coma, or death after a rupture is high.

**Exams and Tests**

Your health care provider will perform a physical exam.

Tests used to diagnose an aneurysm include:

* CT scan
* CT angiogram
* MRI
* MRA (magnetic resonance angiogram)
* Ultrasound
* Angiogram

**Treatment**

Treatment depends on the size and location of the aneurysm. Your provider may only recommend regular checkups to see if the aneurysm is growing.

Surgery may be done. The type of surgery that is done and when you need it depend on your symptoms and the size and type of aneurysm.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your provider if you develop a lump on your body, whether or not it is painful and throbbing.

Go to the emergency room or call 911 or the local emergency number if you have:

* Pain in your belly or back that is very bad or does not go away
* A sudden loss of consciousness (fainting) or severe headache, especially if you also have nausea, vomiting, seizures, or any other nervous system symptom

If you are diagnosed with an aneurysm that has not bled, you will need to have regular testing to detect if it increases in size. In some cases, your provider will suggest early treatment because the aneurysm is large enough.

**Prevention**

Controlling high blood pressure may help prevent many aneurysms. Follow a healthy diet, get regular exercise, and keep your cholesterol at a healthy level to help prevent aneurysms or their complications.

Do not smoke. If you do smoke, quitting will lower your risk for an aneurysm.

---

**Aneurysm: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia (Part 2/4)**

**Causes**

It's often unclear exactly what causes aneurysms. Some aneurysms are present at birth (congenital). Defects in some parts of the artery wall may be a cause.

Common locations for aneurysms include:

*   Major artery from the heart such as the thoracic or abdominal aorta
*   Brain (cerebral aneurysm)
*   Behind the knee (popliteal artery aneurysm)
*   Intestine (mesenteric artery aneurysm)
*   Artery in the spleen (splenic artery aneurysm)

Certain factors or conditions may increase the risk for aneurysms including:

*   High blood pressure (thoracic, abdominal and cerebral aneurysms)
*   High cholesterol
*   Cigarette smoking
*   Illicit drug use (cocaine, amphetamines, methamphetamine)
*   Pregnancy (often linked to splenic artery aneurysms)
*   Family history (sibling, parent, or child)

Inherited disorders that may increase the risk include:

*   Fibromuscular dysplasia (abnormal cell growth in artery walls)
*   Marfan syndrome
*   Polycystic kidney disease
*   Coarctation of the aorta
*   Cerebral arteriovenous malformation (AVM)

**Symptoms**

The symptoms depend on where the aneurysm is located. If the aneurysm occurs near the body's surface, pain and swelling with a throbbing lump is often seen.

Aneurysms in the body or brain often cause no symptoms. Aneurysms in the brain may expand without breaking open (rupturing). The expanded aneurysm may press on nerves and cause double vision, dizziness, or headaches. Some aneurysms may cause ringing in the ears.

If an aneurysm ruptures, pain, low blood pressure, a rapid heart rate, and lightheadedness may occur. When a brain aneurysm ruptures, there is a sudden severe headache that some people say is the "worst headache of my life." The risk of neurologic injury, coma, or death after a rupture is high.

**Exams and Tests**

Your health care provider will perform a physical exam.

Tests used to diagnose an aneurysm include:

*   Ultrasound
*   CT scan
*   MRI

---

**Aneurysm**

An aneurysm is a bulge or sac that forms in the wall of an artery due to weakness or damage. It can occur anywhere in the body, but most often affects the aorta, brain, and other major arteries.

**Symptoms**

* A lump on your body, whether painful or not
* Pain in your belly or back that is very bad or does not go away
* Sudden loss of consciousness (fainting) or severe headache, especially with nausea, vomiting, seizures, or other nervous system symptoms

**Exams and Tests**

Your health care provider will perform a physical exam.

Tests used to diagnose an aneurysm include:

* CT scan
* CT angiogram
* MRI
* MRA (magnetic resonance angiogram)
* Ultrasound
* Angiogram

**Treatment**

Treatment depends on the size and location of the aneurysm. Your provider may only recommend regular checkups to see if the aneurysm is growing.

Surgery may be done, involving a large (open) surgical cut or endovascular embolization, where coils or stents of metal are inserted into a brain aneurysm to make it clot. This reduces the risk for rupture while keeping the artery open.

Aneurysms of the aorta may be reinforced with surgery to strengthen the blood vessel wall.

**Prevention**

Controlling high blood pressure may help prevent many aneurysms. Follow a healthy diet, get regular exercise, and keep your cholesterol at a healthy level to help prevent aneurysms or their complications.

Do not smoke. If you do smoke, quitting will lower your risk for an aneurysm.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your provider if you develop a lump on your body, whether or not it is painful and throbbing.

Go to the emergency room or call 911 or the local emergency number if you have:

* Pain in your belly or back that is very bad or does not go away
* A sudden loss of consciousness (fainting) or severe headache, especially with nausea, vomiting, seizures, or other nervous system symptoms

If you are diagnosed with an aneurysm that has not bled, you will need to have regular testing to detect if it increases in size. In some cases, your provider will suggest early treatment because the aneurysm is large enough.

**Images**

* Cerebral aneurysm
* Aortic aneurysm
* Intracerebellar hemorrhage - CT scan

**References**

Hemphill K, Tierney S, Tirschwell D, Davis AP. A review of methamphetamine use and stroke in the young. Front Neurol. 2024;15:1397677.

Lawrence PF, Rigberg DA. Arterial aneurysms: etiology, epidemiology, and natural history. In: Sidawy AN, Perler BA, eds. Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy. 10th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2023:chap 71.

Lee JJ, Mambelli DD, Britz GW. Surgical approaches to intracranial aneurysms. In: Winn HR, ed. Youmans and Winn Neurological Surgery. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2023:chap 435.

Mills JL, Zachary Sr, Pallister S. Peripheral arterial disease. In: Townsend CM Jr, Beauchamp RD, Evers BM, Mattox KL, eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery. 21st ed. St Louis, MO: Elsevier; 2022:chap 63.

---

**Aneurysm**

\n\n

*   **What is an Aneurysm?**
    An aneurysm is a bulge or sac that forms in the wall of an artery due to weakness or damage. It can occur in any artery, but is most commonly found in the aorta, brain, and legs.
*   **Causes of Aneurysms**
    The exact cause of an aneurysm is often unknown, but it is thought to be related to factors such as:
    *   High blood pressure
    *   Smoking
    *   Family history
    *   Age
    *   Infections or injuries that damage the artery wall
*   **Symptoms of Aneurysms**
    The symptoms of an aneurysm depend on its location and size. Some common symptoms include:
    *   Pain or discomfort in the affected area
    *   Swelling or bruising around the affected area
    *   Shortness of breath (if the aneurysm is located in the chest)
    *   Dizziness or fainting (if the aneurysm is located in the brain)
*   **Treatment of Aneurysms**
    The treatment of an aneurysm depends on its size, location, and symptoms. Treatment options may include:
    *   Surgery to repair or replace the affected artery
    *   Endovascular therapy (inserting a stent or coil into the artery)
    *   Medications to lower blood pressure and prevent further damage

\n\n

*   Aneurysms

title: Angelman syndrome : MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Angelman Syndrome**

_A genetic condition that causes problems with the way a child's body and brain develop_

**Causes**

* This condition involves the gene UBE3A
* Most genes come in pairs, but only the gene passed on from the mother is active
* Angelman syndrome most often occurs because the UBE3A gene passed on from the mother doesn't work the way it should

**Symptoms**

* In newborns and infants:
	+ Loss of muscle tone (floppiness)
	+ Trouble feeding
	+ Heartburn (acid reflux)
	+ Trembling arm and leg movements
* In toddlers and older children:
	+ Unstable or jerky walking
	+ Little or no speech
	+ Happy, excitable personality
	+ Laughing and smiling often
	+ Light hair, skin, and eye color compared to rest of family
	+ Small head size compared to body, flattened back of head
	+ Severe intellectual disability
	+ Seizures
	+ Excessive movement of the hands and limbs
	+ Sleep problems
	+ Tongue thrusting, drooling
	+ Unusual chewing and mouthing movements
	+ Crossed eyes
	+ Walking with arms uplifted and hands waving

**Exams and Tests**

* Genetic tests may diagnose Angelman syndrome by looking for:
	+ Missing pieces of chromosomes
	+ Specific DNA to see if copies of the gene from both parents are in an inactive or active state
	+ A gene variant in the copy of the gene inherited from the mother
* Other tests may include:
	+ Brain MRI
	+ EEG

**Treatment**

* There is no cure for Angelman syndrome, but treatment helps to manage health and development problems caused by the condition
* Anticonvulsant medicines help control seizures
* Behavior therapy helps manage hyperactivity, sleep problems, and development problems
* Occupational and speech therapy manage speech problems and teach living skills
* Physical therapy helps with walking and movement problems

**Support Groups**

* More information and support for people with Angelman syndrome and their families can be found at:
	+ Angelman Syndrome Foundation -- www.angelman.org
	+ AngelmanUK -- www.angelmanuk.org

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

* People with AS live close to a normal lifespan
* Many have friendships and interact socially
* Treatment helps improve function, but people with AS can't live on their own
* They may be able to learn certain tasks and live with others in a supervised setting.

**Possible Complications**

* Severe seizures
* Gastroesophageal reflux (heartburn)
* Scoliosis (curved spine)
* Accidental injury due to uncontrolled movements

---

**Angelman Syndrome**

_A Genetic Condition Affecting Child Development_

**Causes**

Angelman syndrome involves the gene UBE3A. Most genes come in pairs, with children receiving one from each parent. In most cases, both genes are active, but only the gene passed on from the mother is active in the case of UBE3A.

The condition most often occurs because the UBE3A gene passed on from the mother doesn't work the way it should. In some cases, AS is caused when two copies of the UBE3A gene come from the father, and none come from the mother.

**Symptoms**

In newborns and infants:

* Loss of muscle tone (floppiness)
* Trouble feeding
* Heartburn (acid reflux)
* Trembling arm and leg movements

In toddlers and older children:

* Unstable or jerky walking
* Little or no speech
* Happy, excitable personality
* Laughing and smiling often
* Light hair, skin, and eye color compared to the rest of the family
* Small head size compared to body, flattened back of head
* Severe intellectual disability
* Seizures
* Excessive movement of the hands and limbs
* Sleep problems
* Tongue thrusting, drooling
* Unusual chewing and mouthing movements
* Crossed eyes
* Walking with arms uplifted and hands waving

**Exams and Tests**

Genetic tests may diagnose Angelman syndrome by looking for:

* Missing pieces of chromosomes
* Specific DNA to see if copies of the gene from both parents are in an inactive or active state
* A gene variant in the copy of the gene inherited from the mother

Other tests may include:

* Brain MRI
* EEG

**Treatment**

There is no cure for Angelman syndrome. Treatment helps manage health and development problems caused by the condition, including:

* Anticonvulsant medicines to control seizures
* Behavior therapy to manage hyperactivity, sleep problems, and development issues
* Occupational and speech therapy to manage speech problems and teach living skills
* Physical therapy to help with walking and movement problems

---

**Angelman Syndrome**

**Treatment**

There is no cure for Angelman syndrome. Treatment helps to manage health and development problems caused by the condition.

*   Anticonvulsant medicines help control seizures.
*   Behavior therapy helps manage hyperactivity, sleep problems, and development problems.
*   Occupational and speech therapy manage speech problems and teach living skills.
*   Physical therapy helps with walking and movement problems.

**Support Groups**

More information and support for people with Angelman syndrome and their families can be found at:

*   Angelman Syndrome Foundation -- www.angelman.org
*   AngelmanUK -- www.angelmanuk.org

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

People with AS live close to a normal lifespan. Many have friendships and interact socially. Treatment helps improve function. People with AS can't live on their own. However, they may be able to learn certain tasks and live with others in a supervised setting.

**Possible Complications**

Complications may include:

*   Severe seizures
*   Gastroesophageal reflux (heartburn)
*   Scoliosis (curved spine)
*   Accidental injury due to uncontrolled movements

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Contact your health care provider if your child has symptoms of this condition.

**Prevention**

There is no way to prevent Angelman syndrome. If you have a child with AS or a family history of the condition, you may want to talk with your provider before becoming pregnant.

**References**

Kumar V, Abbas AK, Aster JC, Deyrup AT, Das A. Genetic and pediatric diseases. In: Kumar V, Abbas AK, Aster JC, Devrup AT, Das A, eds. Robbins & Kumar Basic Pathology. 11th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2023:chap 4.

Madan-Khetarpal S, Arnold G, Ortiz D. Genetic disorders and dysmorphic conditions. In: Zitelli BJ, McIntire SC, Nowalk AJ, Garrison J, eds. Zitelli and Davis' Atlas of Pediatric Physical Diagnosis. 8th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2023:chap 1.

Yimaz F, Beck CR, Lee C. The chromosomal and genomic basis of disease: disorders of the autosomes and sex chromosomes. In: Cohn RD, Scherer SW, Hamosh A, eds. Thompson & Thompson Genetics and Genomics in Medicine. 9th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2024:chap 6.

**Review Date**

9/18/2023

Updated by: Anna C. Edens Hurst, MD, MS, Associate Professor in Medical Genetics, The University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David C. Dugdale, MD, Medical Director, Brenda Conaway, Editorial Director, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

**Related MedlinePlus Health Topics**

*   Developmental Disabilities
*   Movement Disorders

title: Angelman syndrome: MedlinePlus Genetics
content:
**Angelman Syndrome**

_A complex genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system._

**Description**

Angelman syndrome is a complex genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system. Characteristic features of this condition include delayed development, intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, and problems with movement and balance (ataxia). Most affected children also have recurrent seizures (epilepsy) and a small head size (microcephaly). Delayed development becomes noticeable by the age of 6 to 12 months, and other common signs and symptoms usually appear in early childhood.

Children with Angelman syndrome typically have a happy, excitable demeanor with frequent smiling, laughter, and hand-flapping movements. Hyperactivity and a short attention span are common. Most affected children also have difficulty sleeping and need less sleep than usual.

With age, people with Angelman syndrome become less excitable, and the sleeping problems tend to improve. However, affected individuals continue to have intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, and seizures throughout their lives. Adults with Angelman syndrome have distinctive facial features that may be described as "coarse." Other common features include unusually fair skin with light-colored hair and an abnormal side-to-side curvature of the spine (scoliosis). The life expectancy of people with this condition appears to be nearly normal.

**Frequency**

Angelman syndrome affects an estimated 1 in 12,000 to 20,000 people.

**Causes**

Many of the characteristic features of Angelman syndrome result from the loss of function of a gene called UBE3A. People normally inherit one copy of the UBE3A gene from each parent. Both copies of this gene are turned on (active) in most of the body's tissues. However, in nerve cells (neurons) in the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system), only the copy inherited from a person's mother (the maternal copy) is active. This parent-specific gene activation is caused by a phenomenon called genomic imprinting.

---

**Angelman Syndrome**

**Causes of Angelman Syndrome**

If the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene is lost because of a chromosomal change or a gene variant (also known as a mutation), a person will have no active copies of the gene in most parts of the brain.

Several different genetic mechanisms can inactivate or delete the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene. Most cases of Angelman syndrome (about 70 percent) occur when a segment of the maternal chromosome 15 containing this gene is deleted. In other cases (about 10 to 20 percent), Angelman syndrome is caused by a variant in the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene.

In a small percentage of cases, Angelman syndrome results when a person inherits two copies of chromosome 15 from his or her father (paternal copies) instead of one copy from each parent. This phenomenon is called paternal uniparental disomy. Rarely, Angelman syndrome can also be caused by a chromosomal rearrangement called a translocation, or by a variant or other defect in the region of DNA that controls activation of the UBE3A gene.

The causes of Angelman syndrome are unknown in 10 to 15 percent of affected individuals. Changes involving other genes or chromosomes may be responsible for the disorder in these cases.

**Genetic Factors**

Many of the characteristic features of Angelman syndrome result from the loss of function of a gene called UBE3A. People normally inherit one copy of the UBE3A gene from each parent. Both copies of this gene are turned on (active) in most of the body's tissues. However, in nerve cells (neurons) in the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system), only the copy inherited from a person's mother (the maternal copy) is active.

In some people who have Angelman syndrome, the loss of a gene called OCA2 is associated with light-colored hair and fair skin. The OCA2 gene is located on the segment of chromosome 15 that is often deleted in people with this disorder. However, loss of the OCA2 gene does not cause the other signs and symptoms of Angelman syndrome.

**Inheritance**

Most cases of Angelman syndrome are not inherited, particularly those caused by a deletion in the maternal chromosome 15 or by paternal uniparental disomy. These genetic changes occur as random events during the formation of reproductive cells (eggs and sperm) or in early embryonic development. Affected people typically have no history of the disorder in their family.

Rarely, a genetic change responsible for Angelman syndrome can be inherited. For example, it is possible for a variant in the UBE3A gene or in the nearby region of DNA that controls gene activation to be passed from one generation to the next.

---

**Angelman Syndrome**

**What is Angelman Syndrome?**

Angelman syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects approximately 1 in 14,000 to 1 in 20,000 people worldwide. It is characterized by developmental delays, intellectual disability, and severe motor dysfunction.

**Causes of Angelman Syndrome**

The causes of Angelman syndrome are complex and multifaceted. Most cases are not inherited, particularly those caused by a deletion in the maternal chromosome 15 or by paternal uniparental disomy. These genetic changes occur as random events during the formation of reproductive cells (eggs and sperm) or in early embryonic development.

Rarely, a genetic change responsible for Angelman syndrome can be inherited. For example, it is possible for a variant in the UBE3A gene or in the nearby region of DNA that controls gene activation to be passed from one generation to the next.

**Other Names for This Condition**

* AS
* Prader-Willi Syndrome and Angelman Syndrome

**Additional Information & Resources**

* National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD)
* ClinicalTrials.gov
* Catalog of Genes and Diseases from OMIM
* Scientific Articles on PubMed

**Genetic Testing Information**

* Genetic Testing Registry: Angelman syndrome
* Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center: Angelman syndrome

**References**

1. Buiting K. Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. Am J Med Genet C Semin Med Genet. 2010 Aug 15;154C(3):365-76.
2. Dagli AI, Mathews J, Williams CA. Angelman Syndrome. GeneReviews(R). 1998 Sep 15 [updated 2025 May 1].
3. Gentile JK, Tan WH, Horowitz LT, Bacino CA, Skinner SA, Barbieri-Welge R, et al. A neurodevelopmental survey of Angelman syndrome with genotype-phenotype correlations. J Dev Behav Pediatr. 2010 Sep;31(7):592-601.
4. Lalande M, Calciano MA. Molecular epigenetics of Angelman syndrome. Cell Mol Life Sci. 2007 Apr;64(7-8):947-60.
5. Lossie AC, Whitney MM, Amidon D, Dong HJ, Chen P, Theriaque D, et al. Distinct phenotypes distinguish the molecular classes of Angelman syndrome. J Med Genet. 2001 Dec;38(12):834-45.
6. Pelc K, Cheron G, Dan B. Behavior and neuropsychiatric manifestations in Angelman syndrome. Neuropsychiatr Dis Treat. 2008 Jun;4(3):577-84.
7. Tan WH, Bacino CA, Skinner SA, Anselm I, Barbieri-Welge R, Bauer-Carlin A, et al. Angelman syndrome: Mutations influence features in early childhood. Am J Med Genet A. 2011 Jan;155A(1):81-90.
8. Van Buggenhout G, Fryns JP. Angelman syndrome (AS, MIM 105830). Eur J Hum Genet. 2009 Nov;17(11):1367-73.

Note: The references provided are a selection of the most relevant and up-to-date studies on Angelman syndrome.

---

**Anatomy of Angelman Syndrome**

\n\n

*   **Definition and Prevalence**: Angelman syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by developmental delays, intellectual disability, and severe motor impairment. It affects approximately 1 in 14,000 to 1 in 20,000 individuals worldwide.
*   **Causes and Risk Factors**: The condition is usually caused by mutations or deletions in the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15, which can occur spontaneously or be inherited from a parent. In some cases, Angelman syndrome may be associated with other genetic disorders or chromosomal abnormalities.
*   **Symptoms and Characteristics**:
    *   Developmental delays and intellectual disability
    *   Severe motor impairment, including spasticity and tremors
    *   Happy and affectionate personality traits
    *   Sleep disturbances and epilepsy in some cases
*   **Diagnosis**: Diagnosis is typically made through a combination of clinical evaluation, genetic testing (such as chromosomal microarray or UBE3A gene sequencing), and family history.
*   **Treatment and Management**: There is no cure for Angelman syndrome, but various interventions can help manage symptoms and improve quality of life. These may include:
    *   Physical therapy to enhance motor skills
    *   Occupational therapy to develop daily living skills
    *   Speech therapy to address communication challenges
    *   Medications to control seizures or other related conditions
*   **Prognosis**: With proper care and support, individuals with Angelman syndrome can lead fulfilling lives. While the condition is lifelong, advances in medical treatment and supportive services have improved outcomes and enhanced the overall well-being of those affected.

\n\n

**Understanding Genetics**

\n\n

*   **Inheritance Patterns**: Angelman syndrome can be inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the condition. In some cases, it may be associated with other genetic disorders or chromosomal abnormalities.
*   **Gene Variants and Expression**: The UBE3A gene plays a crucial role in Angelman syndrome. Mutations or deletions in this gene can lead to the development of the condition. Understanding how gene variants affect health and development is essential for identifying and managing related conditions.

\n\n

**Related Health Topics**

\n\n

*   **Developmental Disabilities**: Angelman syndrome is a type of developmental disability characterized by significant cognitive, motor, and communication impairments.
*   **Genetic Disorders**: The condition is a genetic disorder caused by mutations or deletions in the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15.
*   **Movement Disorders**: Individuals with Angelman syndrome often experience severe motor impairment, including spasticity and tremors.

\n\n

**Disclaimers**

\n\n

The information provided on this site should not be used as a substitute for professional medical care or advice. Contact a health care provider if you have questions about your health.

title: Angina - Multiple Languages: MedlinePlus
content:
**Angina**

\n\n

* **What is angina?**
	+ Angina is a type of chest pain or discomfort that occurs when the heart muscle does not receive enough oxygen-rich blood.
	+ It is often caused by coronary artery disease, which is a buildup of plaque in the arteries that supply blood to the heart.
* **Symptoms of angina**
	+ Chest pain or discomfort that may radiate to the arms, back, neck, jaw, or stomach
	+ Shortness of breath or coughing
	+ Fatigue or weakness
	+ Pain or discomfort in the upper body, such as the arms or back
* **Types of angina**
	+ Stable angina: occurs when the heart muscle is not receiving enough oxygen-rich blood due to a blockage in one of the coronary arteries.
	+ Unstable angina: occurs when the heart muscle is not receiving enough oxygen-rich blood due to a sudden and temporary blockage in one or more of the coronary arteries.
	+ Microvascular angina: occurs when there is a problem with the small blood vessels that supply blood to the heart muscle.

\n\n

**Treatment of Angina**

\n\n

* **Lifestyle changes**
	+ Quit smoking
	+ Exercise regularly
	+ Eat a healthy diet
	+ Manage stress
* **Medications**
	+ Nitroglycerin: helps to relax the blood vessels and increase blood flow to the heart muscle.
	+ Beta blockers: help to slow down the heart rate and reduce the amount of oxygen the heart needs.
	+ Calcium channel blockers: help to relax the blood vessels and increase blood flow to the heart muscle.
* **Surgery**
	+ Angioplasty: a procedure that uses a balloon to widen the blocked or narrowed coronary artery.
	+ Bypass surgery: a procedure that creates a new route for blood to flow around a blocked or narrowed section of a coronary artery.

\n\n

**Nitroglycerin**

\n\n

* **What is nitroglycerin?**
	+ Nitroglycerin is a medication that helps to relax the blood vessels and increase blood flow to the heart muscle.
	+ It is often used to treat angina and other conditions that affect the heart.
* **How does nitroglycerin work?**
	+ Nitroglycerin works by releasing nitric oxide, which helps to relax the smooth muscle in the blood vessel walls.
	+ This relaxation allows the blood vessels to dilate, or widen, which increases blood flow to the heart muscle.

\n\n

**Angina**

\n\n

*   **What is angina?**
    Angina, also known as coronary heart disease or ischemic heart disease, is a condition where the heart muscle does not receive enough oxygen due to reduced blood flow. This can cause chest pain or discomfort, often referred to as "heartburn" or "indigestion," although it has nothing to do with digestion.
*   **What are the symptoms of angina?**
    The main symptom of angina is chest pain or discomfort, which can radiate to other areas such as the arms, back, neck, jaw, or stomach. This pain usually occurs during physical activity and resolves within a few minutes after rest or medication.
*   **How is angina diagnosed?**
    Diagnosis typically involves a combination of medical history, physical examination, electrocardiogram (ECG), stress test, and sometimes coronary angiography to visualize the heart's blood vessels.

\n\n

**Treatment Options**

\n\n

*   **Nitroglycerin**
    Nitroglycerin is a medication commonly used to treat angina. It works by relaxing the blood vessels, which helps improve blood flow to the heart muscle.
*   **Other treatment options**
    In addition to nitroglycerin, other treatment options for angina may include lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking, reducing stress, and engaging in regular exercise. Medications like beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, and antiplatelet agents may also be prescribed to manage symptoms and prevent complications.

\n\n

**Language Support**

\n\n

*   **Multilingual resources**
    MedlinePlus offers health information translations in multiple languages, including Korean, Nepali, Portuguese, Russian, Somali, Spanish, Tagalog, and Ukrainian. These resources provide valuable information for individuals who may not speak English fluently or prefer to read about their health concerns in their native language.

\n\n

**Additional Resources**

\n\n

*   **National Library of Medicine**
    The National Library of Medicine provides access to a wide range of health-related materials, including books, journals, and online resources. Visitors can explore these resources to learn more about angina and other health topics.
*   **Health Information Translations**
    MedlinePlus offers bilingual PDFs for various languages, making it easier for individuals to access accurate and reliable health information in their preferred language.

\n\n

**Conclusion**

\n\n

Angina is a serious condition that requires prompt attention. By understanding the symptoms, diagnosis, treatment options, and language support available, individuals can take proactive steps towards managing their angina and maintaining good cardiovascular health.

title: Angina - discharge: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Angina - Discharge**

You were having angina, which is a type of chest discomfort due to poor blood flow through the blood vessels of the heart muscle. This article discusses how to care for yourself when you leave the hospital.

**When You're in the Hospital**

You had this problem when your heart was not getting enough blood and oxygen. You may or may not have had a heart attack.

**What to Expect at Home**

You may feel sad, anxious, and that you have to be very careful about what you do. All of these feelings are normal and should go away for most people after 2 or 3 weeks.

You may also feel tired when you leave the hospital. You should feel better and have more energy within 5 weeks after you are discharged from the hospital.

**Activity**

Know the signs and symptoms of angina:

*   Pressure, squeezing, burning, or tightness in your chest
*   Pressure, squeezing, burning, or tightness in your arms, shoulders, neck, jaw, throat, or back
*   Discomfort in your back, shoulders, and stomach area
*   Indigestion or feeling sick to your stomach
*   Tiredness, shortness of breath, sweating, lightheadedness, or weakness

You may have these symptoms during physical activity, such as climbing stairs, walking uphill, lifting, and engaging in sexual activity. You may also have symptoms more often in cold weather.

**Diet and Lifestyle**

Try to limit how much alcohol you drink. Ask your provider when it is OK to drink, and how much is safe.

Don't smoke cigarettes. If you do smoke, ask your provider for help quitting. Don't let anyone smoke in your home.

Learn more about what you should eat for a healthier heart and blood vessels. Avoid salty and fatty foods. Stay away from fast-food restaurants. Your provider can refer you to a dietitian, who can help you plan a healthy diet.

Try to avoid stressful situations. If you feel stressed or sad, tell your provider. They can refer you to a counselor.

**Taking Your Heart Medicines**

Have all of your prescriptions filled before you go home. You should take your medicines the way you have been told. Ask your provider if you can still take any other prescription medicines, herbs, or supplements you have been taking.

Take your medicines with water or juice. Do not drink grapefruit juice (or eat grapefruit), since these foods may change how your body absorbs certain medicines. Ask your provider or pharmacist about this.

People who have angina often receive the medicines below. But sometimes these medicines may not be safe to take. Talk with your provider if you are not already taking one of these medicines:

*   Antiplatelet medicines (blood thinners), such as aspirin, clopidogrel (Plavix), prasugrel (Efient), or ticagrelor (Brilinta)
*   Other medicines, such as warfarin (Coumadin), to help keep your blood from clotting
*   Beta-blockers and ACE inhibitor medicines, to help protect your heart
*   Statins or other medicines to lower your cholesterol
*   Calcium-channel blockers
*   Nitroglycerin

Never just stop taking any of these medicines. Don't stop taking any other medicines you may be taking for diabetes, high blood pressure, or any other medical problems.

If you are taking a blood thinner, you may need to have extra blood tests to make sure your dose is correct.

**When to Call the Doctor**

Contact your provider if you feel:

*   Pain, pressure, tightness, or heaviness in the chest, arm, neck, or jaw
*   Shortness of breath
*   Gas pains or indigestion
*   Numbness in your arms
*   Sweaty, or if you lose color
*   Lightheaded

Changes in your angina may mean your heart disease is getting worse. Contact your provider if your angina:

*   Becomes stronger
*   Occurs more often
*   Lasts longer
*   Occurs when you are not active or when you are resting
*   If medicines do not help ease your angina symptoms as well as they used to

---

**Angina - Discharge**

When you leave the hospital, you can expect to feel a range of emotions, including sadness and anxiety. These feelings are normal and usually resolve within 2-3 weeks.

**Activity**

Know the signs and symptoms of angina:

*   Pressure, squeezing, burning, or tightness in your chest
*   Pressure, squeezing, burning, or tightness in your arms, shoulders, neck, jaw, throat, or back
*   Discomfort in your back, shoulders, and stomach area
*   Indigestion or feeling sick to your stomach
*   Tiredness, shortness of breath, sweating, lightheadedness, or weakness

These symptoms can occur during physical activity, such as climbing stairs, walking uphill, lifting, or engaging in sexual activity. They may also be triggered by cold weather or occur while resting.

**Diet and Lifestyle**

*   Limit your alcohol intake
*   Avoid smoking cigarettes
*   Learn about a healthy diet for heart health
*   Stay away from salty and fatty foods
*   Try to avoid stressful situations

**Taking Your Heart Medicines**

*   Have all of your prescriptions filled before you go home
*   Take your medicines as directed by your healthcare provider
*   Ask your provider if it's safe to take any other prescription medicines, herbs, or supplements you've been taking

Some common heart medicines include:

*   Antiplatelet medicines (blood thinners) like aspirin, clopidogrel (Plavix), prasugrel (Efient), or ticagrelor (Brilinta)
*   Warfarin (Coumadin) to help prevent blood clots
*   Beta-blockers and ACE inhibitor medicines to protect your heart
*   Statins or other cholesterol-lowering medicines
*   Calcium-channel blockers
*   Nitroglycerin

Never stop taking any of these medicines without consulting your healthcare provider.

**When to Call the Doctor**

Contact your provider if you experience:

*   Pain, pressure, tightness, or heaviness in your chest, arm, neck, or jaw
*   Shortness of breath
*   Gas pains or indigestion
*   Numbness in your arms
*   Sweaty or losing color
*   Lightheaded

Changes in your angina symptoms may indicate worsening heart disease. Contact your provider if:

*   Your angina becomes stronger
*   It occurs more often
*   It lasts longer
*   It happens when you're not active or while resting
*   Medicines no longer ease your symptoms as well as they used to

---

**Angina - Discharge**

You may feel sad and anxious after being discharged from the hospital. These feelings are normal and usually go away within 2-3 weeks.

You may also feel tired when you leave the hospital, but you should start to feel better and have more energy within 5 weeks.

**Know the Signs and Symptoms of Angina**

*   Pressure, squeezing, burning, or tightness in your chest
*   Pressure, squeezing, burning, or tightness in your arms, shoulders, neck, jaw, throat, or back
*   Discomfort in your back, shoulders, and stomach area
*   Indigestion or feeling sick to your stomach
*   Tiredness, shortness of breath, sweating, lightheadedness, or weakness

These symptoms can occur during physical activity, such as climbing stairs, walking uphill, lifting, and engaging in sexual activity. They may also happen in cold weather or when you are resting.

**What to Expect at Home**

Take it easy at first. You should be able to talk easily when doing any activity. If you cannot, stop the activity.

Ask your provider about returning to work and what type of work you will be able to do.

Your provider may refer you to a cardiac rehabilitation program to help you learn how to slowly increase your exercise and take care of your heart disease.

**Diet and Lifestyle**

*   Limit alcohol consumption. Ask your provider when it is okay to drink and how much is safe.
*   Don't smoke cigarettes. If you do smoke, ask your provider for help quitting. Don't let anyone smoke in your home.
*   Eat a healthy diet. Avoid salty and fatty foods. Stay away from fast-food restaurants. Your provider can refer you to a dietitian who can help you plan a healthy diet.
*   Try to avoid stressful situations. If you feel stressed or sad, tell your provider. They can refer you to a counselor.

**Taking Your Heart Medicines**

Have all of your prescriptions filled before you go home. Take your medicines the way you have been told. Ask your provider if you can still take any other prescription medicines, herbs, or supplements you have been taking.

Take your medicines with water or juice. Do not drink grapefruit juice (or eat grapefruit), since these foods may change how your body absorbs certain medicines. Ask your provider or pharmacist about this.

People who have angina often receive the following medicines:

*   Antiplatelet medicines (blood thinners)
*   Other medicines to help keep your blood from clotting
*   Beta-blockers and ACE inhibitor medicines
*   Statins or other medicines to lower your cholesterol
*   Calcium-channel blockers
*   Nitroglycerin

Never just stop taking any of these medicines. Don't stop taking any other medicines you may be taking for diabetes, high blood pressure, or any other medical problems.

---

**Angina - Discharge**

**Medicines You Need to Take**

You will need to take medicines for the rest of your life to prevent more episodes of angina.

*   **Antiplatelet medicines (blood thinners)**: These help keep your blood from clotting. If you are taking a blood thinner, you may need to have extra blood tests to make sure your dose is correct.
*   **Beta-blockers and ACE inhibitor medicines**: These help protect your heart.
*   **Statins or other medicines to lower your cholesterol**: These help prevent hardening of the arteries.
*   **Calcium-channel blockers**: These help relax the muscles in your heart.
*   **Nitroglycerin**: This helps relieve chest pain.

Never just stop taking any of these medicines. Don't stop taking any other medicines you may be taking for diabetes, high blood pressure, or any other medical problems.

**Taking Your Heart Medicines**

Have all of your prescriptions filled before you go home. You should take your medicines the way you have been told. Ask your provider if you can still take any other prescription medicines, herbs, or supplements you have been taking.

Take your medicines with water or juice. Do not drink grapefruit juice (or eat grapefruit), since these foods may change how your body absorbs certain medicines. Ask your provider or pharmacist about this.

**When to Call the Doctor**

Contact your provider if you feel:

*   Pain, pressure, tightness, or heaviness in the chest, arm, neck, or jaw
*   Shortness of breath
*   Gas pains or indigestion
*   Numbness in your arms
*   Sweaty, or if you lose color
*   Lightheaded

Changes in your angina may mean your heart disease is getting worse. Contact your provider if your angina:

*   Becomes stronger
*   Occurs more often
*   Lasts longer
*   Occurs when you are not active or when you are resting
*   If medicines do not help ease your angina symptoms as well as they used to

---

**Angina**

**Causes of Angina**

*   Coronary artery disease (CAD)
*   High blood pressure
*   High cholesterol levels
*   Smoking
*   Family history of heart disease

**Symptoms of Angina**

*   Chest pain or discomfort
*   Shortness of breath
*   Fatigue
*   Pain or numbness in the arms, back, neck, jaw, or stomach

**Types of Angina**

*   Stable angina: occurs when the heart needs more oxygen than usual, such as during exercise
*   Unstable angina: occurs suddenly and can be a sign of an impending heart attack

**Diagnosing Angina**

*   Electrocardiogram (ECG)
*   Stress test
*   Echocardiogram
*   Coronary angiogram

**Treatment of Angina**

*   Lifestyle changes:
    *   Quit smoking
    *   Exercise regularly
    *   Eat a healthy diet
    *   Manage stress
*   Medications:
    *   ACE inhibitors
    *   Antiplatelet medicines (P2Y12 inhibitors)
    *   Aspirin and heart disease
*   Surgical procedures:
    *   Angioplasty and stent placement
    *   Heart bypass surgery
    *   Heart pacemaker
    *   Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator

**Patient Instructions**

*   **ACE Inhibitors**: take as directed by your doctor to help manage blood pressure and reduce the risk of heart disease.
*   **Angina - What to Ask Your Doctor**: discuss your symptoms, medical history, and treatment options with your healthcare provider.
*   **Angina - When You Have Chest Pain**: know what to do when you experience chest pain or discomfort, such as calling emergency services or seeking immediate medical attention.
*   **Angioplasty and Stent - Heart - Discharge**: follow your doctor's instructions for post-procedure care and recovery.
*   **Antiplatelet Medicines - P2Y12 Inhibitors**: take as directed by your doctor to prevent blood clots and reduce the risk of heart disease.
*   **Aspirin and Heart Disease**: discuss with your doctor whether taking aspirin is right for you, especially if you have a history of heart disease or stroke.
*   **Being Active After Your Heart Attack**: engage in regular physical activity, such as walking or light exercise, to help improve cardiovascular health.
*   **Being Active When You Have Heart Disease**: incorporate physical activity into your daily routine to reduce the risk of complications and improve overall well-being.
*   **Butter, Margarine, and Cooking Oils**: choose healthier fats, such as those found in avocados or olive oil, to support heart health.
*   **Cardiac Catheterization - Discharge**: follow your doctor's instructions for post-procedure care and recovery.
*   **Cholesterol and Lifestyle**: maintain a healthy diet, exercise regularly, and manage stress to help regulate cholesterol levels.
*   **Cholesterol - Drug Treatment**: discuss with your doctor whether medication is necessary to lower cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of heart disease.
*   **Controlling Your High Blood Pressure**: work with your healthcare provider to develop a plan for managing blood pressure through lifestyle changes and, if necessary, medication.
*   **Dietary Fats Explained**: understand the differences between various fats, such as saturated and unsaturated fats, to make informed choices about your diet.
*   **Fast Food Tips**: opt for healthier options when eating at fast food restaurants, such as choosing grilled chicken or salads with low-fat dressings.
*   **Heart Attack – Discharge**: follow your doctor's instructions for post-procedure care and recovery.
*   **Heart Attack - What to Ask Your Provider**: discuss your symptoms, medical history, and treatment options with your healthcare provider.
*   **Heart Bypass Surgery - Discharge**: follow your doctor's instructions for post-procedure care and recovery.
*   **Heart Bypass Surgery - Minimally Invasive - Discharge**: follow your doctor's instructions for post-procedure care and recovery.
*   **Heart Disease - Risk Factors**: understand the factors that contribute to heart disease, such as high blood pressure, high cholesterol, smoking, and family history.
*   **High Blood Pressure - What to Ask Your Doctor**: discuss your symptoms, medical history, and treatment options with your healthcare provider.
*   **How to Read Food Labels**: learn how to interpret food labels to make informed choices about the foods you eat.
*   **Mediterranean Diet**: consider incorporating elements of the Mediterranean diet, such as eating more fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and healthy fats, into your lifestyle.

---

**Angina - Discharge**

\n\n

**When You Have Chest Pain**

If you have chest pain, it may be a sign that your heart is not getting enough oxygen. This can happen if the coronary arteries are narrowed or blocked. If you experience chest pain, call for emergency medical services right away.

\n\n

**What to Ask Your Doctor**

Here are some questions you might want to ask your doctor:

*   What caused my angina?
*   How can I prevent future episodes of angina?
*   What lifestyle changes can I make to reduce my risk of heart disease?
*   Are there any medications or treatments that can help manage my angina?

\n\n

**Patient Instructions**

To manage your angina, follow these instructions:

*   Take your medications as directed by your doctor.
*   Make healthy lifestyle choices, such as eating a balanced diet and engaging in regular physical activity.
*   Get enough rest to help reduce stress.
*   Quit smoking if you smoke.

\n\n

**Controlling Your High Blood Pressure**

High blood pressure can increase your risk of heart disease. To control your high blood pressure:

*   Take your medications as directed by your doctor.
*   Make healthy lifestyle choices, such as eating a balanced diet and engaging in regular physical activity.
*   Get enough rest to help reduce stress.
*   Quit smoking if you smoke.

\n\n

**Dietary Fats Explained**

Dietary fats come in different types, including saturated, unsaturated, and trans fats. To manage your angina, focus on consuming healthy fats, such as those found in avocados, nuts, and olive oil.

\n\n

**Fast Food Tips**

When eating fast food, make healthier choices by opting for grilled proteins, vegetables, and whole grains. Limit your consumption of fried foods and sugary drinks.

\n\n

**Heart Attack - What to Ask Your Provider**

If you experience a heart attack, ask your provider the following questions:

*   What caused my heart attack?
*   How can I prevent future episodes of heart disease?
*   What lifestyle changes can I make to reduce my risk of heart disease?
*   Are there any medications or treatments that can help manage my heart disease?

\n\n

**Heart Disease - Risk Factors**

To reduce your risk of heart disease, be aware of the following risk factors:

*   High blood pressure
*   High cholesterol
*   Smoking
*   Family history of heart disease
*   Physical inactivity
*   Obesity
*   Diabetes

\n\n

**High Blood Pressure - What to Ask Your Doctor**

If you have high blood pressure, ask your doctor the following questions:

*   What caused my high blood pressure?
*   How can I lower my blood pressure?
*   What lifestyle changes can I make to reduce my risk of heart disease?
*   Are there any medications or treatments that can help manage my high blood pressure?

\n\n

**How to Read Food Labels**

When reading food labels, look for the following:

*   Saturated fat content
*   Trans fat content
*   Sodium content
*   Sugar content
*   Ingredient list

\n\n

**Mediterranean Diet**

The Mediterranean diet is a healthy eating pattern that can help reduce your risk of heart disease. Focus on consuming whole grains, fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and healthy fats.

\n\n

title: Angina - what to ask your doctor : MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Angina - What to Ask Your Doctor**

Are you experiencing angina, a type of chest pain that occurs when your heart muscle is not getting enough blood and oxygen? Don't worry, we've got you covered. Below are some questions you may want to ask your healthcare provider to help you take care of your angina.

**Questions**

* What are the signs and symptoms that I am having angina? Will I always have the same symptoms?
* What are the activities that can cause me to have angina?
* How should I treat my chest pain, or angina, when it happens?
* When should I call my provider?
* When should I call 911 or the local emergency number?

**Exercise and Activity**

* How much exercise or activity can I do?
* Do I need to have a stress test first?
* Is it safe for me to exercise on my own?
* Where should I exercise, inside or outside? Which activities are better to start with? Are there activities or exercises that are not safe for me?
* How long and how hard can I exercise?

**Work and Daily Life**

* When can I return to work? Are there limits to what I can do at work?
* What should I do if I feel sad or very worried about my heart disease?

**Lifestyle Changes**

* How can I change the way I live to make my heart stronger?
* What is a heart-healthy diet? Is it OK to ever eat something that is not heart healthy? What are some ways to eat healthy when I go to a restaurant?
* Is it OK to drink any alcohol?
* Is it OK to be around other people who are smoking?
* Is my blood pressure normal?
* What is my cholesterol and do I need to take medicines for it?

**Medications**

* What medicines am I taking to treat or prevent angina?
* Do they have any side effects?
* What should I do if I miss a dose?
* Is it ever safe to stop any of these medicines on my own?

**Special Cases**

* If I am taking aspirin, clopidogrel (Plavix), ticagrelor (Brilinta), prasugrel (Effient), or another blood thinner, is it OK to take ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), naproxen (Aleve, Naprosyn), or other pain medicines?
* It is OK to take omeprazole (Prilosec) or other medicines for heartburn?

Remember, your healthcare provider is there to help you. Don't hesitate to ask them any questions you may have about your angina.

**References**
